ansible/roles/prometheus/templates/prome.message: Sets the final shape of the 'instance' label on job's targets - in this case, strips off tcp port number, so values are {hostname} not {hostname:port}

This isn't quite right - we are adding inventory_hostname, but what we add to /etc/hosts is ansible_facts.nodename and ansible_facts.hostname. They could be different.

Also we usually don't assume that people have /etc/hosts or DNS.

If we wanted to fix this and give people a path back to the old way, we could do this:

 prometheus_target_address: "{{ ansible_facts.hostname }}"

Then here:

 {{ hostvars[host].prometheus_target_address | put_address_in_context('url') }}

This should allow people to override prometheus_target_address to api_interface_address to get the old behaviour.

I don't think we should change these assumptions:

* inventory_hostname is arbitrary, and may not relate to hostnames
* hostnames do not need to be resolvable

Do we need to revert this on xena and try again?

I'm just wondering if we are not overthinking this. I ended up with a working config for my suggestion above but I don't like it - each target had its own scraping job definition, but eventually targets of the same kind were grouped with the same job name via relabelling. The config file has grown significantly.

If people are using IPs not names to connect to servers - this should not be fixed / worked around here? They will be presented with an IPs as a names for their targets.

Mark's point is still valid but isn't that a corner case? Should we just discourage inventory_hostname =! ansible_hostname in docs? I'm reluctant to add yet another new variable.
I realised this patch could leave target definitions untouched and focus on the relabeling. We don't have to change how Prometheus connects to the targets, only how it displays them.
That sounds like a good solution.
Using IP addresses as targets would also mean we don't need to update /etc/hosts on the monitoring hosts each time a new compute host is added to the system.
This one could cause issues, since we wouldn't necessarily have the role default for these hosts.
If we were to use a role default, these hosts would not necessarily have it defined. I just realised it could be in group_vars/all.yml though.

etcd3gw/watch.py.message:
Python 2 is no longer supported, what do you think about switching everything to python 3?
I mean I'm not sure to see if this parameter is still required if python 2 isn't supported.

If this parameter is no longer needed too, then I think the test above can be removed too.

Hello,

I missed the HTTP Content-Type header of this topic, so indeed I think you are right the decode_unicode kwargs is not related to the python version and your current approche is better.

I don't think the kwarg is so much related to python2/3 -- the decode_unicode kwarg determines whether or not if requests should decode the content as per the HTTP Content-Type header. [1][2]

[1] https://github.com/psf/requests/blob/b0e025ade7ed30ed53ab61f542779af7e024932e/requests/utils.py#L511
[2] https://github.com/psf/requests/blob/b0e025ade7ed30ed53ab61f542779af7e024932e/requests/models.py#L789

Setting the kwarg is superfluous so long as requests leaves decode_unicode=False as the default.  Or, we could set decode_unicode=True as requests assumes that a content-type of application/json (which should always be the case for etcd) will be encoded in UTF-8 unless explicitly specified otherwise.  We would then need to drop the explicit decoding in the top of the loop, though, to again avoid the AttributeError.

I am impartial to any solution, but what do you think?

IMO the correct thing here is to warn about it being set to service default in next release, it's up to deployment to continue setting it to something else one release after.

Not sure about upgrade impact. Perhaps updating this parameter should happen consistently, otherwise two sides of RPC wouldn't be able to communicate, until restarted with a new config? Also, it might affect custom ha-policies set by operators for rabbitmq, expecting 'openstack' and not 'cinder'. Given that said, I look forward for the experts' feedback on that and how to move this forward (including the related changes needed in cinder).

Meanwhile, the status quo remains as that - one cannot use amqp durable queues with such control_exchange defaults, and the feature remains (and will remain) effectively blocked for years.
Or really, just setting it to os_service_default and it's up to the deployments (or TripleO etc) to set it to something else. It shouldn't be opinionated more than that.

The situation with puppet-neutron is different. Neutron already overrides the default  control_exchange by neutron and current default in puppet-neutron is just re-defining the same
(I'm now removing that redundant default by https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-neutron/+/820279 )

Basically we keep puppet modules as transparent as possible and avoid implementing our own thing. I tend to use service default instead, to prepare for any future change in cinder/manila side instead of hardcoding our own defaults.
agreed. I put fixme to address that once we have the service default in the main code

IMO, we should avoid defining our own default and basically rely on the default in services. I agree it doesn't make sense to define redundant 'openstack' but IMO we should use $::os_service_default, until we hear feedback to your proposals to cinder/manila.

Also, updating control_exchange requires some caution. For example updating this parameter should happen consistently otherwise some services can't communicate each other. Also, it might affect ha-policy in rabbitmq. That's another reason I hesitate to go with this change now.

Greetings Bogdan Dobrelya, 

Would you mind discussing this topic at the cinder meeting to get some attention and feedback on this problem? I think most of the team is leaving for holidays, why don't you add this topic to Jan 12th https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/cinder-yoga-meetings ?
Thanks for the fix. Would there be an upgrade impact with this? Can you please add a release note? https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/contributor/adding_release_notes.html

> At the 2nd sight (kudos to Takashi!), not sure about upgrade impact. Perhaps updating this parameter should happen consistently, otherwise two sides of RPC wouldn't be able to communicate, until restarted with a new config? Also, it might affect custom ha-policies set by operators for rabbitmq, expecting 'openstack' and not 'manila'. Given that said, I look forward for the experts' feedback on that and how to move this forward.

> The status quo is - one cannot use amqp durable queues with such control_exchange defaults, and the feature remains (and will remain) effectively blocked for years.

Yes, this has been my understanding as well. To extend this:

Do we need the exchanges to be isolated between services because other configuration options relating to amqp could conflict between the services that share an exchange? 

Or would it be because you want the topic publishers and subscribers to be isolated per service for best practice? i.e., durable queues allow rabbit agents to all die, and on revival, recover queue contents from memory. So if there are unrelated publishers/subscribers is there any risk of this recovery not happening?


I ask these questions to understand the impact of bricking manila components on an upgrade. When upgrading a cloud, we already prevent communication between newer and older services by virtue of the RPC API Version. So, if the default exchange has changed, there's no real risk that an "older" (un-upgraded) service can no longer communicate with a newer manila service.  However, "newer" services could always pick up and process messages from "older" services - with this change, they will be on a different exchange, so they won't see any messages. This is the real upgrade impact, correct? Is there _any_ way at all that we could avoid this? What do you mean by 

> Perhaps updating this parameter should happen consistently, otherwise two sides of RPC wouldn't be able to communicate, until restarted with a new config?

At the 2nd sight (kudos to Takashi!), not sure about upgrade impact. Perhaps updating this parameter should happen consistently, otherwise two sides of RPC wouldn't be able to communicate, until restarted with a new config? Also, it might affect custom ha-policies set by operators for rabbitmq, expecting 'openstack' and not 'manila'. Given that said, I look forward for the experts' feedback on that and how to move this forward.

The status quo is - one cannot use amqp durable queues with such control_exchange defaults, and the feature remains (and will remain) effectively blocked for years.
Sorry Bogdan, I did not get it! So, changing the default from 'openstack' to 'manila' won't break any user, right ?!

Done.
No upgrade impact since the change is internal to the messaging mechanics.

> However, "newer" services could always pick up and process messages from "older" services - with this change, they will be on a different exchange, so they won't see any messages. This is the real upgrade impact, correct? Is there _any_ way at all that we could avoid this?

yes, but not for the projects, but oslo.messaging. It should provide a fallback mechanism to cover cases when that "old" default exchange disappears. For example, some dispatcher there could introduce by default twice shared control exchanges, one durable by default and the other not, and a switch to decide to publish on one or the other (a dispatcher).
Thank you Bogdan! Just some comments about the units.

tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_node.py.message: Why only when using predictable ips? In general when we extract we should ensure the same fixed_ips for the existing nodes right?

In the case where predictable ips are used, there is a case when the port resource was set to the -from-pool template. So there is no neutron port created. If predictable ips are not used there should be existing neutron ports, when provisioning baremetal again the idempotency should find that there are existing ports and not create new ports. The IPs will then stay the same, as the same port continues to be used.

For Ironic/Ironic-inspector, calls are targeted, so loss of reply we would expect to be handled by oslo messaging. If the service needs to do something (and likely meaning to literally grow oslo messaging expertise), then that needs to be explicit feature work.

A loss of a generalized reply to a call should just be a tolerable failure, albeit visible.

Ironic *does* use notifiers with an expected external collector for object notifications *or* sensor data collection is *enabled*. These are not supported items in a TripleO usage context. If the queue disappears for sensor data, it *appears* the service will just log errors until restarted. For object notifications, prepare is called so I *think* it will be fine.

So I did some testing with this and my other change I am working on and it looks like there is a bit of an issue that the images being built aren't being used by kind here, and instead it is just pulling them down.

You can replicate this by taking the changes to 11_build_images.sh here and using them with this change to make sure that the imagePullPolicy is set to "never":
https://review.opendev.org/c/airship/airshipctl/+/817078/9/tools/airship-in-a-pod/scripts/11_build_images.sh

This will mainly be an issue for whenever a change is modifying the AIAP gate because the changes made in the patchset will not be reflected in the gate.

In order to remedy this you need to load the images into the kind cluster. Here is something I tested with locally that should work integrated into the 11_build_images.sh file:

BUILD_LIST="images artifact-setup base infra-builder runner"
make -e ${BUILD_LIST}

# Load all of the images into the kind cluster

kind load docker-image ${PULL_LIST}
for IMAGE in ${BUILD_LIST}; do
	kind load "quay.io/airshipit/aiap-$IMAGE:latest"
done

paunch/builder/podman.py.message:
this change doesn't mean that ContainerCpusetCpus was not provided. It just means that it's set to the default value.

Are there scenarios where someone would have set ContainerCpusetCpus:all?

Not sure I understand the question.

ContainerCpusetCpus is a role specific parameter[1] with a default 'all'. So 'not provided for a role' means, it's not provided in {{role.name}}Parameters and would use the default value 'all' for that role (nova_libvirt container).

The current issue is when used for a role, it overrides KernealArgs (isolcpus) for remaining roles and uses all cpus for nova_libvirt container. For example for the below case it would use 'all' cpus for Compute1 nova_libvirt container

 Compute1Parameters:
    KernelArgs: "isolcpus=2-21,24-43,45-65,67-87"

  Compute2Parameters:
    ContainerCpusetCpus: "0,22,44,66"

I don't think there would be instances where KernelArgs/ContainerCpusetCpus used together for a role. If ContainerCpusetCpus: 'all' is used without KernelArgs(isolcpus) for a role it would not append  --cpuset-cpus, that would ensure it would use all cpus. If both KernelArgs(isolcpus) and ContainerCpusetCpus: 'all' are used for some reason, it would only use allowed ones (filtered by isolcpus).

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/train/deployment/nova/nova-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml#L262

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
i guess this makes sense the only issue i have with this approach is the vm will like have already elapsed
the soft delete interval when the host comes back up so it probably shoudl be deleted imidetly.

with that said i think this is fine in this case even if it extends the vm lifetime a bit longer.

AFAIK, for all the in-tree drivers, they just stop the guest when calling this.
In theory, there shouldn't be any blocking calls, but given in libvirt we call _cleanup() when destroying the guest (which is done when stopping by default), we try to disconnect volumes or vpmems so we could have issues.

Yeah, if the nova-compute service is up, the problem maybe not exists. If the nova-compute service is down, and we soft deleting the instance without knowing that, the instance maybe have the task-state, and I think we should deal with this case.
... so, here in case we would have cleanup issues when destroying the instance, maybe we should set the instance to ERROR like we do with the above for DELETING task state.

To functionally test it, set `error_suppression_interval = 0` in memcache.conf / your memcache filter config, then cause intermittent delays with something like https://paste.opendev.org/show/810890/ -- without the patch, doing a bunch of listings will eventually deplete the pool, causing everything to come back 401. With the patch, you still get a bunch of logging about trouble talking to or connecting to memcache, but requests will still work.

I take it this is mostly because of clients (such as tempest and swiftclient) wanting to be able to use the full path from the URL when calculating the signature, like in https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/29.2.0/tempest/api/object_storage/test_object_temp_url.py#L71-L77 and https://github.com/openstack/python-swiftclient/blob/3.12.0/swiftclient/shell.py#L1476 ?

The existing notion of "path" is definitely more squishy than I'd like it to be. (Consider, for example, how "/v1/..." and "/v1.0/..." give different signatures. Is that a bug or a feature?) Now I want to check what happens when the client sends an unquoted URL that really *should* have been quoted...

I wonder if we should have a similar option in [app:proxy-server] for the /info endpoint: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.28.0/swift/proxy/controllers/info.py#L80-L85

This makes sense!  I noted a few minor style nits that might be an imporvement; a test would be a welcome addition!

I'd also curious, and you might be able to help us confirm, if a client can send a signature matching the un-prefixed path and it would "just work"?

deploy-guide/source/features/deployed_ce.message: I'm wondering if the "disable" feature should rely on a generated spec (cephadm orch ls --export) or the output of ceph orch ls to see which node has the _admin label (which means that needs the ssh pri key).

but I also see at python-tripleoclient level we can't rely on an input generated by the interaction w/ the ceph cluster. +1 on using the spec (the same generated w/ the deployed metal) to get the list of _admin vs _non_admin nodes.

Right, the tripleo client has no way to get that information from the ceph cluster and it doens't work in the bootstrap scenario anyway. I considered creating a general mechanism to do this in the tripleo client (running ansible from client to overcloud, parsing output, and then taking further action) but was discouraged in the #tripleo channel. Also, that's not going to be as future compatible with the move to task core. I think we'll be changing to using the tripleo client to:

1. genereate_spec(roles.yaml, deployed_metal.yaml)
2. create_user(ceph_spec.yaml)
3. deploy ceph(ceph_spec.yaml)

and use task core to make the above happen in place of ansible but the changes this patch documents creates the 2nd interface.

These tests are in tempest https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/branch/master/tempest/api/network/test_networks.py#L650

and those expects following message to be there in the error: "There are one or more ports still in use on the network". 
So option is to either modify the message in tempest test such that it works with both older and newer message or make the newer message also include the previous message along. Will update the patch as per second option to have less disruption

This is pretty cool from manual user's standpoint, just wondering if it's possible to introduce some app-friendly way of passing these IDs? In Kuryr we could benefit from having the IDs in error, but parsing an error message to get them seems scary.
@Michal not sure about what way you looking for, but can you elaborate more on what way you expecting these to be. others may have opinion there.

Sure! So here's what Neutron API returns on such errors:

 http://10.1.10.46:9696 "DELETE /v2.0/networks/e10886c7-0e3d-4b6d-aa00-0abaca77c8a7 HTTP/1.1" 409 205
 RESP: [409] Content-Length: 205 Content-Type: application/json Date: Thu, 16 Dec 2021 17:07:56 GMT X-Openstack-Request-Id: req-5f247056-98e6-4ccc-bf0c-228384351058
 RESP BODY: {"NeutronError": {"type": "NetworkInUse", "message": "Unable to complete operation on network e10886c7-0e3d-4b6d-aa00-0abaca77c8a7. There are one or more ports still in use on the network.", "detail": ""}}

As you can see the body of the response is a JSON. In case I'd want my app to attempt to delete ports preventing deletion of the network, when such error occurs, I'd need to parse the NeutronError.message string. My point is that it would be cool to have e.g. conflict_list field there that would have these IDs in form of a JSON list.

This might be out of scope of the patch, I get it, just showing a possible improvement.

neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py.message: as non_auto_ports are fetched from DB with context of the user who made request, it if fine to just return list of those ports here and not leak anything to the user. So I'm ok with this.

I think that the command-line arguments aren't getting overwritten, similar to what was happening with Fedora 35.  This was because the machine-id was missing, and I suspect something similar.  I will comment in the bug

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
This is happening on Stream-9 initial image, which means the target as far as this change hasn't moved.

But perhaps this is just a first time in CI as opposed to a local machine in UEFI mode?

My impression is we believe grub2-mkconfig should be updating/overwriting the config, but I believe this only happens depending on the mode of the machine, and these jobs are running in bios mode which behaves a little differently from what has been observed.

My feeling is this is the centos image V the centos-minimal image.  

The situation is confusing between grub-mkconfig and grubby.  [1] sort-of discusses it.

I am still fairly convinced that grub2-mkconfig is the right tool for dib to be using in a generic sense here.  This spans platforms, releases and does not require bifurcating the bootloader path -- leaving the grub2-mkconfig path broken and not matching correctly led to the Fedora 35 failures which were equally hard to unravel (and we can't just revert this as-is, without fixing that too).

9-stream grub2-mkconfig has code intended to update the BLS kernel parameters [2] -- and we know it works because it updates our centos-minimal 9-stream kernel correctly.

This is why I would like to root-cause *why* it's not working here.  machine-id mismatch?  something set by the upstream image in /etc/default/grub?

This is complicated by the fact that our boot tests happen on Ubuntu Focal, which doesn't have kernel support to be able to open the xfs on centos-9 .qcow2 images -- i.e. we can not do an end-to-end test on the centos (not -minimal) element.

I'll keep looking, but this is my current thinking. 

[1] https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/fedora/f34/system-administrators-guide/kernel-module-driver-configuration/Working_with_the_GRUB_2_Boot_Loader/

[2] https://gitlab.com/redhat/centos-stream/rpms/grub2/-/blob/c9s/0074-Add-BLS-support-to-grub-mkconfig.patch#L230

tripleo_ansible/playbooks/disable_cephad.message:
So you're running this playbook against "allovercloud" but adding the --limit ceph_mon[0] (1)
Just out of curiosity: Is there a particular reason behind this change or di you hit an issue? 

(1) https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/820449/4/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_run_cephadm/tasks/disable_cephadm.yml#29

> So you're running this playbook against "allovercloud" but adding the --limit ceph_mon[0] (1)
> Just out of curiosity: Is there a particular reason behind this change or di you hit an issue? 

The ceph_mon group doesn't exist when you use deployed ceph. The ansible inventory was created by networkv2 but Heat has not yet run.

So, when the playbook is called from THT we can use the ceph_mon group this way:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/820449/4/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_run_cephadm/tasks/disable_cephadm.yml

But when it's called from deployed ceph we cannot reference the ceph_mon group as it is not in the ansible inventory. Thus, I use the ceph_spec to identify one of the hosts with the _admin label and pass that host directly via limit here:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/820407/8/tripleoclient/v2/overcloud_ceph.py#500
Ack thanks, I missed the fact we don't have a config-download/ceph compatible inventory at that stage.

"You can also set the DNS resolver address to 0.0.0.0 for IPv4 subnets, or :: for IPv6 subnets, which are special values that indicate to the DHCP agent that it should not announce any DNS resolver at all on the subnet."

The word 'address' is used, it doesn't cover the case where there are 'addresses' present.

In my opinion we should just filter the 0.0.0.0/:: and use the resultant list, which might be an IP address(es). I think the code above actually changes the behavior, it used to return both if they were present and now it will return none.

I don't agree with this interpretation and doesn't make sense. But this is what is implemented [1] in the DHCP agent right now and the goal of this patch is to mimic the current behaviour.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/e99d9a9d0697a21ba7ec84465f415f60041f3767/neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py#L1156-L1165

hooks/install.message:
My concern here is that this is non-repeatable - the contents of the python package index can change, and by building the virtualenv at runtime we potentially hit issues between units deployed today working, and units deployed in +1yr not working.

Reactive works around this by only installing from the wheelhouse that was made when the charm was built and published to the charm store.

This is actually the primary reason that this change is currently WF-1, I wanted to open it up for discussion so I made a basic change that does it.

If we want to actually go down this path, I'll probably want to replicate some of the work that layer-basic does in terms of re-exec for the python interpreter to allow us to start our hook in /usr/bin/env python3 and then end up running the charm code in our virtualenv.

Alternately, we could expand on this pattern + a wheelhouse, and go from there :-)

I'm +1 to doing this from a wheelhouse. That would still require a set of "charmhelpers sync" pull requests whenever we updated a tool in charmhelpers. But that pull request would just be a nice simple replacement of one tarball in the wheelhouse with a new tarball, rather than a messy blat of files in the charm.

I'm also +1 to executing via /usr/bin/env python3 rather than referencing the bin in the virtualenv explicitly. That will make things less of a headache if we change approaches down the line.

In general, though, this is a great idea, and I like it :-)
